data.title: The Red Ibis (1975)
data.meta_description: A mentally disturbed man named Jérémie is scouring the area in search of women he can strangle with his scarf, which is embroidered with an ibis.
data.text:
Adored in France and virtually unseen anywhere else, Jean-Pierre Mocky's cockeyed adaptation of Fredric Brown's taut crime novel Knock Three-One-Two (previously given a more straightforward adaptation on Boris Karloff's Thriller) is a whirligig of peculiar characters whose fates intersect in a canal-adjacent neighborhood. A freckled strangler (Michel Serrault) with a fetish for flies on cleavage is running amuck and distinguished by the bird-patterned red scarf he wears, while aging street vendor Michel Simon (in his last performance) wants to take credit for the crimes when he isn't haggling off an aggressive attempt to buy his seaside house. Simon also totes around a little kid who keeps eating bananas, which somehow isn't the weirdest thing in the film. Toss in a restaurateur with a gambling problem, jewelry, a possibly unfaithful wife, non-consensual Greek dancing, and a wacko score by Eric Demarsan, and the result is a very memorable film that defies categorization.

Je sais que c'est du Mocky et qu'il aime l'absurde, mais là c'était un peu trop pour moi. Michel Simon a l'air de bien s'amuser et le film est court, ce qui rend le visionnage moins douloureux. Mais globalement c'est assez gênant à regarder et ça a la fâcheuse tendance de s'éparpiller le plus possible. Je ne peux même pas dire que ça vaut au moins le coup pour le trio de Michel connus au cœur du film parce qu'ils n'ont pas la même importance à l'écran.

C'est complètement voulu et assumé, certains adoreront le ton adopté par le film et sa bizarrerie, mais ça m'a pas parlé.
